--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "Jeff Nielsen" <jeff.nielsen@d...> wrote:
> B=
y calling an (overloaded) class method from within the constructor 
> you'r=
e getting into no man's land with the intricacies of the Java 
> runtime. 
=

Well, it's not recommended, but I wouldn't call it "no man's land".
It's p=
retty clearly specified. The problem I've seen in the past with
calling ove=
rridden methods in a constructor is that the variables in
the subclass are =
initialised *after* the superclass constructor
returns. That means any chan=
ges you make to the subclass variables in
the overridden method are lost (a=
t least if there is explicit
initialisation). It also means that the method=
 will be called without
the initialisation having taken place, so it's effe=
ctively running in
a partially constructed context.

So yes, it's generally=
 not a good idea, but very occasionally it can
be the simplest way of worki=
ng, and it should certainly work in the
OP's case - and does for me... I'd =
be interested to try to work out
exactly why it doesn't on the OP's box.

J=
on
